body.p:
Your letter on your return home duly reached
me. I regret very sincerely to learn of your impaired health, of which
my Richmond correspondents had before informed me; but most earnest-
ly do I pray that further tidings may be of a happier character.

The lukewarmness and indifference that
you noticed in your recent Southern trip, in religious matters, had
long ago been perceptible to me, and occasioned serious and painful
thought. This degeneracy has been creeping along for some time and
I see fearful signs of its continuous progress. The battle between
Principle and Gain almost invariably terminates in favor of the
latter; hence those leaders who will smooth away the “difficulties”
which beset the path of conformity with recognized duties, and
not insist on the uncompromising fidelity required of us, are
certain of being popular and influential. My “dilenda est
Carthago” is the onslaught in and out of the Pulpit on the
modern manufacture of a “Religion of Convenience.” I have
confidence in the innate piety and good sense of the people
who often, tho offenders against the the Law, do not palliate
or argue away the wrong, and may be wrought on for their

good Hebrew; but when Teachers rise up, and by
precept and example inculcate as unimportant, useless, and
contrary to the spirit of the age — all or much of what they had
been trained up to observe — what is to be expected? The awakened
religious feelings become enlisted in favor of what requires so little
effort; only build a magnificent place of worship, modernize,
hope? & render agreeable its services, preserve decorum, & have an
external varnish of piety, and the Hebrew is attained. I place
a great deal of the blame for this wretched state of affairs
on the shoulders of our so-called Orthodox chiefs, who are idle &
selfish, and contribute nothing to the general good of Israel. All
their efforts seem concentrated on little aims which began in their
own Synagogues and end there. And then there is no unity of
action. Look for assistance at the several large congregations at
the North. At the 19th St. Synagogue, everything seems to have been
attained in Mr Lyn's? cadences & his choir's artistic performances.
The pulpit is silent, and does not seem to be needed. Our
worthy brethren there are apparently contented with the order of
things as they are, and are either so pious as not to require
explanations or so wicked as to fear denunciation. At Dr. Raphall's
& Mr. Isaacs's, I hear trumpet-tongued praises of the choir, in
the former, it is said, led by a Xian! Do you not remember my
fickle and unsuccessful effort in ? at the first Sephim of
the Board of Delegates to have its scope of a character which

might meet our wants;- a College — preparatory Schools — a
supervising Board to examine into the qualifications & personal
worth of those coming to this country for office&c? But no: it
seemed that the assembly of Delegates from various parts of the
Union looked only to the aggrandizement of New York, and we
Dummies had only to listen with rapt attention to the to the Delphic
oracles & play the meek parts of “make weights.” I hope
better things are in progress for I notice at last, some wakefullness
on the great needs of one day. But perhaps my expectations
are premature, and another Rip Van Winkle nap will follow.

Your article in the June No. is sound &
telling, and I trust to see it followed up by some tangible plan
for training up an American ministry. It is singular that
our wealthy Congrns. have not been influenced even by common
policy to do something even of a selfish nature for their own
future advantage; and I throw out the hint which you might
use, that lacking any general or organized effort, that each
might devote a portion of its funds annually set apart to edu
cate in Europe — after the usual Collegiate Course here — a
respectable & pious-minded young man, in whose services it
would have the first claim. My little boy I purpose, God
willing, bringing up to the sacred profession, and if nothing better, or
as good offer here at the proper age to send him to Breslau; and
all my strivings peculiarly are devoted towards this attainment,

not depending on any Congregational action. I wish a few others
would attempt the same procedure. I can but hope it.

Mr. Aletrino has shown some diligence
in the matter of the Agency, and has handed me the following bit of
additional subscribers, to whom please mail the Occident,—if possible
from the Nissan No. when the present Vol. began. If you cannot do this
to all, endeavor to do so for the Messrs. De Meza.—Joshua D Henriques,
E. de Pina, Morris Woolf, A de Sola, J. O. DeCastro, S J de Meza,
A H de Meza, & Henry Aaron. Mr B Y Benyamin is still uncertain
as to subscribing. Send a list of amts due you by previous Sub.
for collection. Send the follg Books p Express—addressed to Mr
M Alentino, 80 Prytania St. - N.O.

As soon as he collects for these and subsns. I will see that the amt.
be promptly remitted you.

I hinted to Mr. Gutheim of his long silence;
and I understood him to say he would soon write you. Perhaps he
has already done so. The Rampart St. synagogue is to be torn down &
made more spacious, the adjoining lot having been purchased. The Polish
on Colonial ? to be finished for Hebrew, that on Jackson St for Hebrew
Mrs. Jacobs joins me in kind regards.
